awd_titl_txt: SCC-CIVIC-PG Track B: Creating a community-centered framework to address inequities in food-security in Alaskan coastal communities facing a changing climate
awd_abstract_narration:
Accessing healthy food resources is a significant challenge for rural coastal Alaskan communities, which are predominantly comprised of Indigenous Alaskans who rely on subsistence foods that are nutritionally and culturally important. Addressing these concerns is urgent, as food safety and security are increasingly threatened by environmental toxicants due to climate change and pollution, and requires approaches that enable communities to make proactive decisions and respond to rapid changes in essential resources. Many food-safety monitoring programs in geographically isolated communities currently rely on contributory citizen science models, where citizen-collected samples are sent off-site to academic or agency research labs for analyses. This model has been shown to enhance participant knowledge and engagement, but it is prone to delays in communicating results, and may magnify inequities, technological gaps, and distrust. The project's vision seeks to flip this paradigm and create an effective community-centered research partnership where all steps from identifying the problem, to data collection, analysis, and processing, will be led by and take place within the community through support from research and technology partnerships. The proposed pathway will be applicable for a range of geographically isolated, rural communities working to incorporate local and traditional knowledge and scientific data on food safety into natural resource management decisions.

THis research-centered pilot project is a partnership between academic researchers and tribal governments in Alaska. The Aleut Community of St. Paul Island (ACSPI) identified concerns surrounding food security and safety as an area ripe for innovation and one which would benefit from partnering with western scientists. To address our research question “Does a community-centered citizen science framework address inequities in food security, improve quality of life, and enhance resilience for Alaskan coastal communities?” this project will (1) develop on-site research capacity for ecosystem health monitoring through sustainable enhancements to existing research infrastructure and technology, (2) expand community engagement in data collection, analysis, and interpretation by leveraging “two-eyed seeing” approaches to scientific training and educational programming, and (3) develop a digital dashboard for data archival, accessibility, and sharing capacity to facilitate information utilization and resilience, within and between communities. This holistic program builds upon existing partnerships, frameworks, and trust, which will enable us, during the Stage 1 planning grant, to focus on expanding and refining our team, honing the training module design, solidifying deliverables based on community needs, and ensuring successful completion within the pilot project timeframe. This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program—Track B. Bridging the gap between essential resources and services & community needs—and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Aleut Community of St. Paul Island (ACSPI) Tribal Government is dedicated to enhancing tribally-led research that addresses the concerns of community members and provides critical data that will shape environmental policy and management plans within the Bering Sea region. ACSPI has focused on fostering relationships with academic partners that are committed to equity and success for the tribal community. Through this CIVIC Stage 1 Planning Grant, ACSPI worked with University of Alaska partners to identify and create solutions for addressing the community?s concerns about safety of traditional foods as environmental conditions around their home rapidly change. 

Intellectual Merit: During this Stage 1 Planning grant, we completed our goal of developing and submitting a CIVIC Stage 2, Pilot Project proposal. The vision for this Pilot Project is a unique contaminant monitoring program in which community members will be able to deliver tissue samples of their traditional foods to  an on-site Community Program Coordinator who will measure contaminants in real time. This CIVIC partnership will allow community members to exchange knowledge with University researchers, allowing the community to monitor their harvests and build their own guidelines for safe food consumption. The team worked collaboratively on all aspects of proposal development from identifying deliverables, to writing, and budget development. 

To achieve this goal, we accomplished our objective of expanding our Core Team to be community-centered, equitable, interdisciplinary, and diverse. The Core Team and broader senior personnel for the proposed Stage 2 Pilot Project were expanded to include Unangax̂ Alaska Native civic partners and community residents as co-leaders in the proposed project. Mr. Roberts is an Island Sentinel in the Ecosystem Conservation Office (ACSPI), and is also a tribal member. He has extensive experience in subsistence harvests and monitoring of wildlife populations on the island, and he will bring this expertise to his role as Community Program Coordinator. As the Indigenous Sentinels Network (ISN) Coordinator (ACSPI), Miss Garcia brings her extensive expertise in data collection and organization, and in training community members in the use of the ISN database application. New partners from the University that have expertise in food safety and security, and environmental contaminants also joined the team (Drs. Barst and Fried), providing additional interdisciplinary expertise to tackle the community-driven questions and concerns during the proposed Pilot Project. The foundation of trust, equity, and professional development generated through this project will enable the community of St. Paul to pursue the Pilot Project successfully, but also explore other partnerships and opportunities as priorities and concerns evolve. 

Broader impacts: This project also provided teaching and educational experiences, and broadened participation in STEM in a very focused way, concentrating on individuals within Tribal Government employment and women. St. Paul Island is predominantly Alaska Native (82%). In this project, Tribal member Mr. Roberts traveled to the University of Alaska Fairbanks to learn the process of analyzing tissues for mercury concentrations and to provide thoughts and feedback for how we might be most effective in implementing our vision. Mr. Roberts is exemplary of the braided river model of training we have chosen as the framework for our project - he has not taken a traditional educational path to his current position, and rather has utilized St. Paul Island as his ?classroom? all his life. Early career and established women from the university and Tribal government organizations also participated in all activities during this project, gaining experience in aspects of program development, implementation, and evaluation. These efforts will be strengthened and enhanced in the proposed Stage 2 project, with additional goals of improved capacity to blend local and Indigenous perspectives with western scientific methods and findings 

Finally, we connected with many other Tribal and environmental organizations from Alaska and the Arctic region to identify opportunities for synergy and relationship building in the proposed Stage 2 project. For example, the Indigenous Sentinel Advisory Assembly, composed of representatives and Elders from across the region, will serve as a guide and connector for any future work. We also were invited to speak at the US Arctic Research Commission (USARC) about our Stage 1 project and vision for Stage 2 Pilot Project. This informational presentation brought additional awareness about the community concerns related to food security and contaminants, and our innovative approaches of how to address these challenges, to leading science and policy experts in the Arctic.  

Through our efforts in expanding and mentoring our project team, writing the Stage 2 proposal, and communicating with other regional stakeholders and advisory bodies about the research question and proposed work, this Planning Grant project is likely to impact society by demonstrating the potential of what can be accomplished by building upon and expanding community strengths through an equitable community-university partnership.

Modified by: Amanda Bishop
